awd_titl_txt: Automated decomposition of optimization problems through learning network structures
awd_abstract_narration:
Large-scale complex optimization problems have become increasingly important for control or dynamic optimization of chemical processes, including design or operation in an uncertain economic environment and integration of process design, control and scheduling at the enterprise-wide level. These problems are inherently non-scalable and computationally difficult to solve. Decomposition is a type of solution method where the larger problem is "decomposed" into multiple, easier-to-solve sub-problems. Decomposition based solution methods are computationally efficient for solving large optimization problems, but they rely on intuition for decomposing the optimization formulation into a set of interacting sub-problems that can be solved iteratively to obtain the optimum.  The proposed research project aims to generalize this approach and eliminate the need for applying heuristics (intuition) by developing an automated framework for determining the most suitable decomposition structure and corresponding solution method.

The proposed research aims to develop a generic framework for learning the underlying structure of a complex optimization problem, finding the corresponding decomposition consistent with this structure, and adapting the decomposition to account for integer variables and nonconvex constraints to improve the corresponding solution strategy. The developed framework will be automated through the development of open-source software packages for analyzing the structure of optimization problems and executing decomposition-based algorithms based on high-level programming languages. A stochastic block model will be introduced as a powerful statistical inference tool for analyzing network representations (variable-constraint graphs) of optimization problems. Within this framework, the most suitable block structure underlying the optimization problem topology (community structure, core-periphery structure, or hybrid structure) will be systematically determined, it will be refined to accommodate integer variables and nonconvex constraints and will be matched with the corresponding decomposition-based solution algorithms. Graduate students will be trained in fundamental research cutting across mathematics, optimization and network science. Undergraduate research projects inspired from this research projects will be offered as honors thesis research projects to undergraduate students at the University of Minnesota. The PI will mentor and host students from DeLaSalle High School in Minneapolis, which has a diverse student population, to cultivate their interest in pursuing STEM careers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Large-scale and complex optimization problems arise naturally in process design, control, planning, scheduling, and their integration. Their efficient solution is essential towards addressing major technological and sustainability challenges as they relate to designing new products, processes, and supply chains. Decomposition-based solution methods  are a common and natural approach to improving the computational tractability of such problems. They rely on decomposing the optimization formulation into interacting subproblems that need to be solved iteratively to the optimum. Yet, this partitioning of the optimization variables and constraints into different groups to form subproblems is typically performed based on intuition. Determining systematically the most suitable decompositions of optimization problems according to their structure, in concert with the corresponding decomposition-based solution method, has been a crucial and open problem.

Research under this grant has adopted methods from modern network science  aimed at detecting block structures in networks. These methods (community detection and stochastic block models) were applied to challenging optimization problems that arise in process systems engineering. It was demonstrated that they can reveal the natural hierarchical levels and their structure  in integrated planning, scheduling, and dynamic optimization problems and allow us to exploit this structure for more efficient solutions, often through novel formulations. Methods for the coordination of the constituent optimization problems that result from such decompositions, guaranteeing that it achieves  the true optimum and it does so in a stable and computationally efficient fashion, were also developed. The theoretical advances were implemented to many benchmark problems, documenting their benefits in terms of computational performance or quality of the solution. One of the proposed methods was adopted and implemented industrially in the Shell-Yokogawa control platform. A  software package for the automated decomposition of optimization problems was also developed. Two graduate students were trained as part of this award and they have both joined academic institutions as Assistant Professors.
